channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Popping the Question, Tuhao-Style
item.description: Expensive marriage proposals in China have been criticized online using a newly coined word.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM CENTURY
item.media:description: Xu Pengjie posted shoes to show his Weibo followers that he was serious about giving out 1,000 pairs during his marriage proposal.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Dominican Republic: Fearful Haitians Deported or Voluntarily Flee
item.description: At least 350 Haitians and people of Haitian descent have either been expelled from the Dominican Republic or left on their own accord in recent days after two Dominicans were killed, said Lolo Sterne, coordinator for Haiti’s Office of Migration, on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Wanted Exile’s Attempt to Surrender Is Rejected
item.description: The second most-wanted student leader from the 1989 Tiananmen Square pro-democracy protests was turned back from Hong Kong on Monday in his latest attempt to surrender to Chinese authorities and return home.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Dispute Erupts in India Over Surveillance by Candidate
item.description: Government eavesdropping on a woman in India has been traced to Narendra Modi, Gujarat State’s chief minister, and it has spurred a discussion of the state’s use of surveillance.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: An eavesdropping case involving Narendra Modi, an opposition figure, is unlikely to alienate his supporters, who attended a rally in New Delhi on Saturday.

item.title: U.S. and Saudis in Growing Rift as Power Shifts
item.description: The United States-Saudi relationship is still close, but their interests are not as aligned as they once were.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT F. WORTH
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry was escorted by the Saudi foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, as he arrived in Riyadh on Nov. 3.

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: A Divided Rio de Janeiro, Overreaching for the World
item.description: Local officials are struggling to reinvent this onetime third-world city with a first-world economy, but progressive ideals are running up against age-old, intractable problems.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

item.title: Obama Signals a Shift From Military Might to Diplomacy
item.description: The announcements of an interim nuclear deal with Iran and a conference on Syria’s civil war were vivid statements that diplomacy has again become the centerpiece of American foreign policy.
item.category: Institute for Science and International Security
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: “For the first time in a decade, we’ve halted the progress on Iran’s nuclear program,” Mr. Obama said on Monday.

item.title: Egypt’s Government Struggles to Gain Footing as Dissent Grows
item.description: It has become harder for officials to blame the Muslim Brotherhood for all the nation’s problems, nearly five months after it was swept from power.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students who support Mohamed Morsi, the deposed president, demonstrated in the Nasr City section of Cairo on Sunday.

item.title: New Left-Wing Party in Honduras Cries Foul
item.description: Juan Orlando Hernández had a lead over Xiomara Castro, whose party, Libre, said it would contest the results, setting the stage for unrest.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS PHILLIPS and ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Juan Orlando Hernández, the presidential candidate of the governing National Party, arrived for a news conference on Monday in Tegucigalpa.

item.title: Militia in Benghazi Flees After Deadly Gun Battle
item.description: The fighting followed the deaths of at least 43 people in Tripoli this month and came as rival factions flex their muscles ahead of a bid to elect a constitutional assembly.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Libyan army troops during clashes with Ansar al-Shariah, a local hard-line Islamist group, on Monday in Benghazi.

item.title: New Clues May Change Buddha’s Date of Birth
item.description: At a temple in Nepal that contains a pillar documenting a homage at the Buddha’s birthplace, researchers determined that lower structures were erected as early as the sixth century B.C.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD
item.media:description: Archaeologists have uncovered a series of ancient temples within the Maya Devi Temple in Nepal.

item.title: Memo From Jerusalem: Israelis See Ticking Clock, and Alternate Approaches, on Iran and Palestinians
item.description: To some, Israel’s differing approach to the Iran nuclear negotiations and to peace talks with the Palestinians is a sign of hypocrisy. Others say it is an existential necessity.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Domestic Drones Ready
item.description: The Pakistani military deployed its first fleet of domestically developed drones on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: The Vatican: Putin Meets the Pope
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met with Pope Francis in the Vatican on Monday, and their first encounter was primarily focused on the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Attacks Kill at Least 23 People
item.description: A series of bombings and shootings on Monday left at least 23 people dead and more than 20 wounded, Iraqi security officials and medical workers said.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: The Lede: Egyptians Vow to Fight New Protest Ban
item.description: While a new law banning protests in Egypt was roundly mocked online, activists immediately applied for a permit to test it, by organizing a protest against the measure.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Obama’s Visiting Security Adviser Tells Karzai to Sign Agreement
item.description: Susan E. Rice told President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan to sign a security agreement or potentially face the complete pullout of American troops by the end of 2014, officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Lens Blog: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
item.description: Photos from Libya, Thailand, Ukraine and Indonesia.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Well: Heart Attack Pain Similar for Men and Women
item.description: A new study found that too much has been made of gender differences in chest pain, the hallmark symptom of heart disease.
item.dc:creator: By RONI CARYN RABIN

item.title: Talks on Ending Syria’s Civil War to Begin in January
item.description: The aim is to create a transitional government based on mutual consent, though the Syrian government and the opposition are still far apart on what that would mean.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: November 25
item.description: State assembly elections in progress in the central state of Madhya Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Women queuing up outside a polling station in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh, to cast their votes in the state assembly elections. The results will be announced on Dec. 8.

item.title: Currents: A New Boom Starting Up in Dubai
item.description: Entrepreneurs who stayed in Dubai after the financial crisis, or arrived as others fled, wonder if this kingdom can foster a capitalism from below.
item.dc:creator: By ANAND GIRIDHARADAS
item.media:description: The skyline of Dubai, which is recovering from the global financial crisis.

item.title: Posters Elicit German Tips Concerning Nazi Crimes
item.description: The Simon Wiesenthal Center, which runs the campaign, has passed information about four people to the authorities for further investigation.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Courses Offer Help in Decoding the Third Plenum
item.description: Chinese universities are offering cram courses on deciphering the Communist Party’s recently unveiled Third Plenum reform plan, suggesting that foreigners are not the only ones scratching their heads.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM CENTURY
item.media:description: One change called for by the Third Plenum report is the abolition of the re-education through labor system, this cartoon from Xinhua News Agency explains.

item.title: Oil Prices Dip on Iran Deal, but Exports May Not Rise
item.description: Easing tensions with Tehran could bring more of its oil and natural gas to global markets, but analysts didn’t see much change in market fundamentals.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED
item.media:description: Even before the announcement Sunday, American drivers were likely to pay less at the gas pump this Thanksgiving than they did last year.
